text: hi everyone needs a nice leap tanto here
the Internet's busiest music nerd and
it's time for a review of the new big
thief album two hands two of them this
is the newest full-length LP from
buzzing in defaulters big thief fronted
by currently one of the most distinct
singers in the genre right now Adrian
linker big thief has been making quite a
bit of headway over the past few years
the band's mix of intricate but
enchanting folk instrumentation and odd
but expressive lead vocals have not only
earned them a 4ad record contract but
also leagues of diehard fans ready to go
to the mat for them and while their
record you FoF earlier this year was
definitely a breakout moment for them
despite the wide praise amongst fans and
many publications I just could not bring
myself to get into it as much I just did
not see what was so profound about it
meanwhile while I don't love the band's
2017 record capacity at least that album
was a bit more focused consistent seemed
like it had an identity meanwhile you
FoF in comparison is so the scattershot
unsure of its direction and occasionally
despite the unique characteristics of
big thief's music drowning in its
influences just not not that strong of a
personality to it so with this wave of
success that big thief is writing the
band is doing something that is rare for
a group in indie folk especially one
that is up-and-coming and that is drop
two albums within five months of each
other where all these tracks written in
workshop and recorded within that time
period I don't know but either way it's
a lot of music to be dropping in such a
short amount of time big picture I
suppose it does make sense as big thief
is just as subjected to the over
saturation of the music industry as any
rapper making three mixtapes a year is I
went into this record worried though
that there would be no reason to even
listen to it because within this span of
time how would big thief come through
with a distinct sound instead of songs
that actually feels different from you
FoF and hopefully more appealing to me
than you FoF but the band actually did
it and not by indulging in a bunch of
experiments and abstractions know this
record is very much about big thief
taking it back to basics instrumentally
I would say it's kind of the spiritual
successor to capacity as in the
tracklist here the banned folds one
tuneful expressive subtly weird folk
tune on top of another sure the
production is not as slick as it was on
UFO f there are not as many bells and
whistles but there's really nothing to
distract from the focus of just
delivering some quality straightforward
solid songwriting here which when you're
talking about a genre is simple and is
rustic generally as folk music can't be
a bad thing now maybe this is to a point
where some of the instrumental pallets
here are a bit bland
like on the very subdued those girls or
on these somewhat breezy replaced or
maybe a song such as the intro comes off
a little brief under written still
though there's a very nice handful of
highlights on this thing most of the
tracks on this record are incredibly
enjoyable for one the track forgotten
highs one of the most solid and/or
playable songs and spanned has ever put
out
I love the rich acoustic chords on this
track I love how nimble and dynamic
linkers vocals are she's just ice
dancing on this instrumental easily one
of her best performances on the entire
record and the song has this lovely
almost romantic intoxicating quality to
it just gets me swaying immediately and
I'm so taken with the lyrics on this one
too which range from being incredibly
surreal but beautiful forgotten eyes are
the ones which we lose forgotten hands
are the ones which we choose then we get
spots on the same track that are
wonderfully relatable like everybody
needs a home and deserves protection hmm
I also love the track two hands with
these speedy quickly played guitar
arpeggios and the somewhat metallic and
rickety percussion in the background it
hits a good pace all this sets a very
simple and a raw foundation for linkers
slightly low five vocal performance here
it's a wonderfully organic in the moment
recording that just feels so intimate
also that melodic transition into the
chorus the
it's just so warm and inviting and
welcoming it feels familiar but also
refreshing and new leggers voice reminds
me of points of like a violin we also
have the track not which is a grim piece
of full crock with lots of distorted
extended guitar solos it reaches this
urgent darkness that reminds me of like
an old classic Neil Young song or two
and wolf despite being one of the
quietest tracks here is easily one of
the most compelling and worthwhile the
hypnotic acoustic finger-picking is
tight as hell the rustic lead melodies
as well as some of linkers most poetic
writing on the entire project the sense
of longing on this track is so thick you
could cut it with a knife stab it with a
fork scoop it with a spoon I don't have
an incredible amount of praise for this
record past this point but it is a very
good in solid set of tracks
I enjoyed it certainly much more than
big thief's last record I may be in the
minority on that but it is what it is I
would love to hear the band in the
future be able to build on this sound
without losing sight of these
characteristics that make them what they
are and even though there are a handful
of tracks here that I wish were more
fleshed out or a bit bolder I still find
this to be a very solid and enjoyable
indie folk record a don't miss if you're
a die-hard for the genre I'm feeling a
light too decent seven on this one
transition have you given this album a
listen did you love it did you hate it
what would you rate it you're the best
you're the best what should I review

subscribe and please don't cry hit the
bell is well over here next to my head
is a another video for you to check out

Anthony Fantana big thief's forever
